code:
export const blogPosts = [{
  id: 1,
  title: "The Science Behind Seed-Bearing Lollipops: How We Made the Impossible Possible",
  slug: "science-behind-seed-bearing-lollipops",
  author: "Taylor Johnson",
  authorRole: "Founder & Chief Botanical Officer",
  publishDate: "2024-01-15",
  category: "Innovation",
  readTime: "5 min read",
  excerpt: "Ever wondered how we embed living seeds into candy without compromising their viability? Take a peek behind the curtain at our proprietary process.",
  content: `When people first hear about Amborella Organics, their immediate reaction is usually: "Wait, how is that even possible?" We get it – the idea of a lollipop that grows into a plant sounds like something out of Charlie and the Chocolate Factory.

But here's the beautiful truth: it's not magic, it's science. And after three years of research and development, we've perfected a process that keeps seeds viable while creating the most delicious organic lollipops you've ever tasted.

## The Challenge

The biggest hurdle wasn't the candy-making – it was preserving seed viability. Seeds are living organisms that need specific conditions to remain viable. Traditional candy-making involves high temperatures that would destroy seeds instantly.

## Our Solution

We developed a proprietary low-temperature process that allows us to embed seeds at temperatures that won't compromise their ability to germinate. Each seed is carefully coated with a biodegradable protective layer that shields it from moisture and temperature fluctuations during the candy-making process.

## The Biodegradable Stick

Perhaps the most innovative part isn't the candy itself – it's the stick. Made from compressed organic plant fibers and natural binding agents, our sticks are designed to break down in soil within 30-60 days, releasing the embedded seeds at the perfect time for germination.

The future of confectionery isn't just about taste – it's about impact. And we're just getting started.`,
  featuredImage: "blog-science-behind-lollipops.jpg",
  tags: ["Innovation", "Science", "Sustainability"],
  featured: true
}, {
  id: 2,
  title: "Growing Your First Herb Garden: A Beginner's Guide with Amborella",
  slug: "growing-first-herb-garden-beginners-guide",
  author: "Maria Santos",
  authorRole: "Head of Growing Programs",
  publishDate: "2024-01-08",
  category: "Gardening",
  readTime: "7 min read",
  excerpt: "Never grown anything before? No problem! Here's everything you need to know to turn your lollipop sticks into a thriving herb garden.",
  content: `Starting your first garden can feel overwhelming, but with Amborella's seed-bearing lollipops, you're already halfway there! Here's your complete guide to growing success.

## Choosing Your Location

Most herbs love sunlight, so pick a spot that gets 6-8 hours of direct sun daily. If you're growing indoors, a south-facing window works perfectly.

## Planting Your Lollipop Stick

1. **Timing**: Wait 24-48 hours after finishing your lollipop to ensure all candy residue has dissolved
2. **Depth**: Plant the stick horizontally, about 1/4 inch deep
3. **Spacing**: Leave 2-3 inches between sticks if planting multiple
4. **Watering**: Keep soil consistently moist but not waterlogged

## What to Expect

- **Week 1-2**: Seeds begin to germinate (you might see tiny green shoots)
- **Week 3-4**: First true leaves appear
- **Week 6-8**: Plants are established and ready for first harvest (for herbs like basil and sage)

## Common Mistakes to Avoid

- **Overwatering**: More herbs die from too much water than too little
- **Poor drainage**: Ensure your pots have drainage holes
- **Harvesting too early**: Let plants establish before taking cuttings

Remember, gardening is a journey, not a destination. Every gardener kills plants – it's how we learn!`,
  featuredImage: "blog-beginners-herb-garden.jpg",
  tags: ["Gardening", "Herbs", "Beginner"],
  featured: true
}, {
  id: 3,
  title: "From Oprah to Your Garden: The Story Behind Our Media Attention",
  slug: "from-oprah-to-your-garden-media-story",
  author: "Taylor Johnson",
  authorRole: "Founder & Chief Botanical Officer",
  publishDate: "2024-01-01",
  category: "Company",
  readTime: "4 min read",
  excerpt: "How a simple idea born in a Laguna Beach kitchen caught the attention of Oprah, Forbes, and millions of people worldwide.",
  content: `It started with a simple question: "What if candy could give back to the planet?"

## The Kitchen Experiment

Three years ago, I was experimenting in my Laguna Beach kitchen, trying to figure out how to embed seeds into candy without killing them. After countless failed attempts (and a very patient partner who endured the smell of burnt sugar for months), we had our first successful prototype.

## The Oprah Moment

When Oprah featured us in her "Favorite Things," we were operating out of a 200-square-foot space. Within 24 hours, we received orders that would normally take us six months to fulfill. It was terrifying and exhilarating at the same time.

## Forbes Recognition

Being recognized by Forbes for innovation wasn't just about business – it validated that sustainable confectionery could be a real industry disruptor. We weren't just making candy; we were creating a new category.

## The NowThis Viral Video

9.9 million views later, that video taught us something crucial: people are hungry for products that don't just taste good but do good. Every view represented someone who believed in our mission.

## What's Next

Media attention is wonderful, but what matters most is every single person who plants one of our sticks and watches something beautiful grow. That's the real story – the millions of small gardens blooming all over the world.

The future is growing, one lollipop at a time.`,
  featuredImage: "blog-media-attention-story.jpg",
  tags: ["Company", "Media", "Story"],
  featured: false
}, {
  id: 4,
  title: "The Environmental Impact of Traditional Candy vs. Seed-Bearing Treats",
  slug: "environmental-impact-traditional-vs-seed-bearing-candy",
  author: "Dr. Elena Rodriguez",
  authorRole: "Sustainability Consultant",
  publishDate: "2023-12-20",
  category: "Sustainability",
  readTime: "6 min read",
  excerpt: "A deep dive into the environmental footprint of conventional confectionery and how seed-bearing candy is changing the game.",
  content: `The confectionery industry produces over 180 million pounds of candy annually in the US alone. What if instead of just consuming, we could contribute to the planet's health with every sweet treat?

## Traditional Candy's Environmental Cost

- **Packaging waste**: Most candy comes in non-recyclable plastic wrappers
- **Plastic sticks**: Conventional lollipop sticks are made from polypropylene plastic
- **Sugar production**: Industrial sugar farming depletes soil and requires heavy water usage
- **Transportation**: Long supply chains increase carbon footprint

## The Amborella Difference

Our seed-bearing lollipops flip this equation:

- **Biodegradable sticks**: Break down naturally in soil within 60 days
- **Organic ingredients**: Support regenerative farming practices
- **Carbon negative**: Each planted stick potentially sequesters more carbon than was used in production
- **Minimal packaging**: Compostable wrappers made from plant-based materials

## The Ripple Effect

When you plant an Amborella stick, you're not just growing a plant:
- **Pollinators**: Flowering herbs support declining bee populations
- **Soil health**: Plant roots improve soil structure and water retention
- **Air quality**: Even small plants contribute to oxygen production
- **Biodiversity**: Native herb varieties support local ecosystems

## The Numbers

Based on independent analysis, if just 1% of conventional lollipops were replaced with seed-bearing alternatives:
- 50,000 fewer pounds of plastic waste annually
- 2.3 million new plants contributing to carbon sequestration
- Measurable positive impact on pollinator populations

Small choices, big impact. That's the Amborella way.`,
  featuredImage: "blog-environmental-impact.jpg",
  tags: ["Sustainability", "Environment", "Impact"],
  featured: false
}, {
  id: 5,
  title: "Seasonal Planting Guide: When to Plant Your Amborella Seeds",
  slug: "seasonal-planting-guide-when-to-plant",
  author: "James Chen",
  authorRole: "Master Gardener",
  publishDate: "2023-12-15",
  category: "Gardening",
  readTime: "8 min read",
  excerpt: "Maximize your growing success by understanding the best times to plant different Amborella varieties throughout the year.",
  content: `Timing is everything in gardening. While our seeds can technically be planted year-round indoors, understanding seasonal patterns will dramatically improve your success rate.

## Spring (March-May)

**Best for**: Sage, Basil, Marigold, Lemongrass
Spring's gentle warming is perfect for most of our varieties. Start indoors 6-8 weeks before your last frost date.

### Spring Success Tips:
- Use a seed starting heat mat for consistent temperature
- Provide 12-14 hours of light daily (grow lights work great)
- Gradually acclimate plants before moving outdoors

## Summer (June-August)

**Best for**: Lavender, Rosemary, Thyme
Heat-loving herbs thrive in summer's warmth. Direct outdoor planting works well in most climates.

### Summer Success Tips:
- Plant in early morning or evening to avoid heat stress
- Mulch around plants to retain moisture
- Provide afternoon shade in extremely hot climates (90°F+)

## Fall (September-November)

**Best for**: Chamomile, Elder, Echinacea
Fall's cool, moist conditions are ideal for flowers and medicinal herbs.

### Fall Success Tips:
- Plant 10-12 weeks before first expected frost
- Focus on cold-hardy varieties
- Consider cold frames for extended growing season

## Winter (December-February)

**Best for**: Indoor growing only
Winter is perfect for starting your spring garden indoors.

### Winter Success Tips:
- Set up a dedicated growing area with proper lighting
- Maintain consistent temperatures (65-75°F)
- Be patient – growth will be slower in winter months

## Regional Considerations

### USDA Zones 9-11 (Southern regions):
You can grow almost everything year-round! Take advantage of your longer growing season.

### USDA Zones 6-8 (Temperate regions):
Follow seasonal guidelines closely. Consider extending seasons with cold frames or row covers.

### USDA Zones 3-5 (Northern regions):
Focus on indoor growing in winter. Start early indoors for best outdoor results.

Remember: These are guidelines, not rules. Every garden is unique, and experimentation is part of the fun!`,
  featuredImage: "blog-seasonal-planting-guide.jpg",
  tags: ["Gardening", "Seasonal", "Planting"],
  featured: false
}];
export const categories = [{
  id: 'all',
  name: 'All Posts'
}, {
  id: 'innovation',
  name: 'Innovation'
}, {
  id: 'gardening',
  name: 'Gardening'
}, {
  id: 'sustainability',
  name: 'Sustainability'
}, {
  id: 'company',
  name: 'Company News'
}];
export const getFeaturedPosts = () => blogPosts.filter(post => post.featured);
export const getPostBySlug = slug => blogPosts.find(post => post.slug === slug);
export const getPostsByCategory = category => category === 'all' ? blogPosts : blogPosts.filter(post => post.category.toLowerCase() === category);
export const getRecentPosts = (limit = 3) => blogPosts.sort((a, b) => new Date(b.publishDate) - new Date(a.publishDate)).slice(0, limit);

sourcesContent:
export const blogPosts = [
  {
    id: 1,
    title: "The Science Behind Seed-Bearing Lollipops: How We Made the Impossible Possible",
    slug: "science-behind-seed-bearing-lollipops",
    author: "Taylor Johnson",
    authorRole: "Founder & Chief Botanical Officer",
    publishDate: "2024-01-15",
    category: "Innovation",
    readTime: "5 min read",
    excerpt: "Ever wondered how we embed living seeds into candy without compromising their viability? Take a peek behind the curtain at our proprietary process.",
    content: `When people first hear about Amborella Organics, their immediate reaction is usually: "Wait, how is that even possible?" We get it – the idea of a lollipop that grows into a plant sounds like something out of Charlie and the Chocolate Factory.

But here's the beautiful truth: it's not magic, it's science. And after three years of research and development, we've perfected a process that keeps seeds viable while creating the most delicious organic lollipops you've ever tasted.

## The Challenge

The biggest hurdle wasn't the candy-making – it was preserving seed viability. Seeds are living organisms that need specific conditions to remain viable. Traditional candy-making involves high temperatures that would destroy seeds instantly.

## Our Solution

We developed a proprietary low-temperature process that allows us to embed seeds at temperatures that won't compromise their ability to germinate. Each seed is carefully coated with a biodegradable protective layer that shields it from moisture and temperature fluctuations during the candy-making process.

## The Biodegradable Stick

Perhaps the most innovative part isn't the candy itself – it's the stick. Made from compressed organic plant fibers and natural binding agents, our sticks are designed to break down in soil within 30-60 days, releasing the embedded seeds at the perfect time for germination.

The future of confectionery isn't just about taste – it's about impact. And we're just getting started.`,
    featuredImage: "blog-science-behind-lollipops.jpg",
    tags: ["Innovation", "Science", "Sustainability"],
    featured: true
  },
  {
    id: 2,
    title: "Growing Your First Herb Garden: A Beginner's Guide with Amborella",
    slug: "growing-first-herb-garden-beginners-guide",
    author: "Maria Santos",
    authorRole: "Head of Growing Programs",
    publishDate: "2024-01-08",
    category: "Gardening",
    readTime: "7 min read",
    excerpt: "Never grown anything before? No problem! Here's everything you need to know to turn your lollipop sticks into a thriving herb garden.",
    content: `Starting your first garden can feel overwhelming, but with Amborella's seed-bearing lollipops, you're already halfway there! Here's your complete guide to growing success.

## Choosing Your Location

Most herbs love sunlight, so pick a spot that gets 6-8 hours of direct sun daily. If you're growing indoors, a south-facing window works perfectly.

## Planting Your Lollipop Stick

1. **Timing**: Wait 24-48 hours after finishing your lollipop to ensure all candy residue has dissolved
2. **Depth**: Plant the stick horizontally, about 1/4 inch deep
3. **Spacing**: Leave 2-3 inches between sticks if planting multiple
4. **Watering**: Keep soil consistently moist but not waterlogged

## What to Expect

- **Week 1-2**: Seeds begin to germinate (you might see tiny green shoots)
- **Week 3-4**: First true leaves appear
- **Week 6-8**: Plants are established and ready for first harvest (for herbs like basil and sage)

## Common Mistakes to Avoid

- **Overwatering**: More herbs die from too much water than too little
- **Poor drainage**: Ensure your pots have drainage holes
- **Harvesting too early**: Let plants establish before taking cuttings

Remember, gardening is a journey, not a destination. Every gardener kills plants – it's how we learn!`,
    featuredImage: "blog-beginners-herb-garden.jpg",
    tags: ["Gardening", "Herbs", "Beginner"],
    featured: true
  },
  {
    id: 3,
    title: "From Oprah to Your Garden: The Story Behind Our Media Attention",
    slug: "from-oprah-to-your-garden-media-story",
    author: "Taylor Johnson",
    authorRole: "Founder & Chief Botanical Officer",
    publishDate: "2024-01-01",
    category: "Company",
    readTime: "4 min read",
    excerpt: "How a simple idea born in a Laguna Beach kitchen caught the attention of Oprah, Forbes, and millions of people worldwide.",
    content: `It started with a simple question: "What if candy could give back to the planet?"

## The Kitchen Experiment

Three years ago, I was experimenting in my Laguna Beach kitchen, trying to figure out how to embed seeds into candy without killing them. After countless failed attempts (and a very patient partner who endured the smell of burnt sugar for months), we had our first successful prototype.

## The Oprah Moment

When Oprah featured us in her "Favorite Things," we were operating out of a 200-square-foot space. Within 24 hours, we received orders that would normally take us six months to fulfill. It was terrifying and exhilarating at the same time.

## Forbes Recognition

Being recognized by Forbes for innovation wasn't just about business – it validated that sustainable confectionery could be a real industry disruptor. We weren't just making candy; we were creating a new category.

## The NowThis Viral Video

9.9 million views later, that video taught us something crucial: people are hungry for products that don't just taste good but do good. Every view represented someone who believed in our mission.

## What's Next

Media attention is wonderful, but what matters most is every single person who plants one of our sticks and watches something beautiful grow. That's the real story – the millions of small gardens blooming all over the world.

The future is growing, one lollipop at a time.`,
    featuredImage: "blog-media-attention-story.jpg",
    tags: ["Company", "Media", "Story"],
    featured: false
  },
  {
    id: 4,
    title: "The Environmental Impact of Traditional Candy vs. Seed-Bearing Treats",
    slug: "environmental-impact-traditional-vs-seed-bearing-candy",
    author: "Dr. Elena Rodriguez",
    authorRole: "Sustainability Consultant",
    publishDate: "2023-12-20",
    category: "Sustainability",
    readTime: "6 min read",
    excerpt: "A deep dive into the environmental footprint of conventional confectionery and how seed-bearing candy is changing the game.",
    content: `The confectionery industry produces over 180 million pounds of candy annually in the US alone. What if instead of just consuming, we could contribute to the planet's health with every sweet treat?

## Traditional Candy's Environmental Cost

- **Packaging waste**: Most candy comes in non-recyclable plastic wrappers
- **Plastic sticks**: Conventional lollipop sticks are made from polypropylene plastic
- **Sugar production**: Industrial sugar farming depletes soil and requires heavy water usage
- **Transportation**: Long supply chains increase carbon footprint

## The Amborella Difference

Our seed-bearing lollipops flip this equation:

- **Biodegradable sticks**: Break down naturally in soil within 60 days
- **Organic ingredients**: Support regenerative farming practices
- **Carbon negative**: Each planted stick potentially sequesters more carbon than was used in production
- **Minimal packaging**: Compostable wrappers made from plant-based materials

## The Ripple Effect

When you plant an Amborella stick, you're not just growing a plant:
- **Pollinators**: Flowering herbs support declining bee populations
- **Soil health**: Plant roots improve soil structure and water retention
- **Air quality**: Even small plants contribute to oxygen production
- **Biodiversity**: Native herb varieties support local ecosystems

## The Numbers

Based on independent analysis, if just 1% of conventional lollipops were replaced with seed-bearing alternatives:
- 50,000 fewer pounds of plastic waste annually
- 2.3 million new plants contributing to carbon sequestration
- Measurable positive impact on pollinator populations

Small choices, big impact. That's the Amborella way.`,
    featuredImage: "blog-environmental-impact.jpg",
    tags: ["Sustainability", "Environment", "Impact"],
    featured: false
  },
  {
    id: 5,
    title: "Seasonal Planting Guide: When to Plant Your Amborella Seeds",
    slug: "seasonal-planting-guide-when-to-plant",
    author: "James Chen",
    authorRole: "Master Gardener",
    publishDate: "2023-12-15",
    category: "Gardening",
    readTime: "8 min read",
    excerpt: "Maximize your growing success by understanding the best times to plant different Amborella varieties throughout the year.",
    content: `Timing is everything in gardening. While our seeds can technically be planted year-round indoors, understanding seasonal patterns will dramatically improve your success rate.

## Spring (March-May)

**Best for**: Sage, Basil, Marigold, Lemongrass
Spring's gentle warming is perfect for most of our varieties. Start indoors 6-8 weeks before your last frost date.

### Spring Success Tips:
- Use a seed starting heat mat for consistent temperature
- Provide 12-14 hours of light daily (grow lights work great)
- Gradually acclimate plants before moving outdoors

## Summer (June-August)

**Best for**: Lavender, Rosemary, Thyme
Heat-loving herbs thrive in summer's warmth. Direct outdoor planting works well in most climates.

### Summer Success Tips:
- Plant in early morning or evening to avoid heat stress
- Mulch around plants to retain moisture
- Provide afternoon shade in extremely hot climates (90°F+)

## Fall (September-November)

**Best for**: Chamomile, Elder, Echinacea
Fall's cool, moist conditions are ideal for flowers and medicinal herbs.

### Fall Success Tips:
- Plant 10-12 weeks before first expected frost
- Focus on cold-hardy varieties
- Consider cold frames for extended growing season

## Winter (December-February)

**Best for**: Indoor growing only
Winter is perfect for starting your spring garden indoors.

### Winter Success Tips:
- Set up a dedicated growing area with proper lighting
- Maintain consistent temperatures (65-75°F)
- Be patient – growth will be slower in winter months

## Regional Considerations

### USDA Zones 9-11 (Southern regions):
You can grow almost everything year-round! Take advantage of your longer growing season.

### USDA Zones 6-8 (Temperate regions):
Follow seasonal guidelines closely. Consider extending seasons with cold frames or row covers.

### USDA Zones 3-5 (Northern regions):
Focus on indoor growing in winter. Start early indoors for best outdoor results.

Remember: These are guidelines, not rules. Every garden is unique, and experimentation is part of the fun!`,
    featuredImage: "blog-seasonal-planting-guide.jpg",
    tags: ["Gardening", "Seasonal", "Planting"],
    featured: false
  }
];

export const categories = [
  { id: 'all', name: 'All Posts' },
  { id: 'innovation', name: 'Innovation' },
  { id: 'gardening', name: 'Gardening' },
  { id: 'sustainability', name: 'Sustainability' },
  { id: 'company', name: 'Company News' }
];

export const getFeaturedPosts = () => blogPosts.filter(post => post.featured);
export const getPostBySlug = (slug) => blogPosts.find(post => post.slug === slug);
export const getPostsByCategory = (category) => 
  category === 'all' ? blogPosts : blogPosts.filter(post => post.category.toLowerCase() === category);
export const getRecentPosts = (limit = 3) => 
  blogPosts.sort((a, b) => new Date(b.publishDate) - new Date(a.publishDate)).slice(0, limit);
